While v is often taken as the “statistical value” of human life, existing public health policies, including organ transplant selection, tend to value life years, which brings up the uncomfortable topic regarding the age bias of any given disease (e.g., H1N1 and COVID-19 have the opposite age biases). Indeed, focusing on lives instead of life years easily produces reductio ad absurdum type of arguments in public health (e.g., spending $8 million per dose on a new drug that extends life expectancy by minutes). If so, the age bias of COVID-19 would tend to reduce the case for mass quarantines.
